text: At a 4-way stop intersection, two vehicles arrive at the same time from different directions. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right
The vehicle on the left
The larger vehicle
Whoever honks first
explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously at a 4-way stop, the driver on the right has the right-of-way. This rule prevents confusion and reduces the risk of collisions.

text: At a 4-way stop, if you arrive first, when should you proceed?
choices: After coming to a complete stop and when it is safe
Immediately without stopping
After waiting for all other vehicles
Only when another driver signals you to go
explanation: The first vehicle to arrive at a 4-way stop and come to a complete stop has the right-of-way and may proceed when safe. This maintains orderly traffic flow.

text: At an uncontrolled intersection where there are no signs or signals, who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right
The vehicle traveling faster
The vehicle on the left
The vehicle that arrives first
explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way when two vehicles arrive at approximately the same time. Always approach these intersections with caution.

text: You are turning left at an intersection with a green light. Oncoming traffic is approaching. What should you do?
choices: Yield to oncoming traffic before turning
Turn immediately since you have a green light
Honk and proceed with caution
Wait for the light to turn yellow
explanation: Even with a green light, vehicles turning left must yield to oncoming traffic traveling straight. Left-turning vehicles must wait for a safe gap in traffic.

text: At a T-intersection, you are on the through street and another vehicle is at the end of the T. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way on the through street
The vehicle at the end of the T
Whoever arrives first
The larger vehicle
explanation: Traffic on the through street at a T-intersection has the right-of-way over vehicles entering from the terminating street. The entering vehicle must yield.

text: You are entering a roundabout. Traffic is already circulating inside. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles already in the roundabout
You, as the entering vehicle
Vehicles to your left
Whoever is driving faster
explanation: Vehicles already circulating in a roundabout always have the right-of-way. Entering vehicles must yield until there is a safe gap to merge.

text: You arrive at an intersection with a stop sign. What must you do before proceeding?
choices: Come to a complete stop and yield to traffic
Slow down and proceed if clear
Stop only if other vehicles are present
Honk and proceed slowly
explanation: A stop sign requires a complete stop before the stop line or crosswalk. You must yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians before proceeding safely.

text: At a 4-way stop, three vehicles arrive at the same time. Vehicle A is on your right, Vehicle B is across from you, and you are Vehicle C. Who goes first?
choices: Vehicle A on your right
You (Vehicle C)
Vehicle B across from you
All vehicles proceed together
explanation: When multiple vehicles arrive simultaneously at a 4-way stop, the vehicle on the right has priority. In this case, Vehicle A has the right-of-way.

text: You are at a 4-way stop and want to turn left. A vehicle across from you arrives at the same time and wants to go straight. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle going straight
You, turning left
Whoever proceeds first
Both can go simultaneously
explanation: When two vehicles face each other at an intersection, straight-through traffic has the right-of-way over left-turning traffic. Wait for the straight vehicle to clear before turning.

text: You approach an intersection where the traffic signal is not working. How should you treat this intersection?
choices: As a 4-way stop
As an uncontrolled intersection where you can proceed freely
As a yield sign for all directions
As a green light for your direction
explanation: When traffic signals are not functioning, all drivers must treat the intersection as a 4-way stop. Come to a complete stop and proceed according to right-of-way rules.

text: You see a yield sign at an intersection. What does this mean?
choices: Slow down and give right-of-way to other vehicles and pedestrians
Stop completely before proceeding
Proceed without slowing if the road is clear
Honk to warn other drivers
explanation: A yield sign requires you to slow down and be ready to stop, giving the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians. You may proceed only when it is safe to do so.

text: At a 4-way stop, you arrive second. The first vehicle is turning left across your path, and a third vehicle arrives after you on your right. When do you proceed?
choices: After the first vehicle completes their turn, before the third vehicle
After both the first and third vehicles
At the same time as the third vehicle
Before the first vehicle completes their turn
explanation: At a 4-way stop, proceed in order of arrival. Since you arrived second, you go after the first vehicle clears, and before the third vehicle that arrived after you.

text: You are turning right at an intersection. A vehicle is approaching from the left intending to turn left onto the same street. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle turning left from the opposite direction
You, turning right
Whoever signals first
Whoever completes the turn faster
explanation: When both vehicles are turning onto the same street, the vehicle making the left turn generally has the right-of-way over the right-turning vehicle to avoid collision in the intersection.

text: You are driving on a two-lane road and want to turn left into a driveway. Oncoming traffic is approaching. What should you do?
choices: Yield to oncoming traffic before turning
Turn quickly before oncoming traffic reaches you
Signal and expect oncoming traffic to stop
Turn only if you can complete it in under 3 seconds
explanation: Drivers turning left across oncoming traffic must yield the right-of-way to vehicles traveling straight. Wait for a safe gap before turning.

text: When making a right turn at a red light (where permitted), what must you do first?
choices: Come to a complete stop and yield to all traffic and pedestrians
Slow down and proceed if clear
Honk to alert other drivers
Wait for the green light
explanation: Before turning right on red, you must come to a complete stop and yield to all vehicles and pedestrians. Proceed only when safe and where right turns on red are permitted.

text: At an uncontrolled intersection, you and another vehicle approach from perpendicular directions at about the same time. You are both going straight. Who yields?
choices: You yield if the other vehicle is on your right
The other vehicle always yields to you
Whoever is traveling faster proceeds first
Both vehicles should stop and wait
explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, when two vehicles arrive simultaneously, the vehicle on the left must yield to the vehicle on the right. This is the fundamental right-of-way rule.

text: You are in a roundabout and want to exit. A vehicle is trying to enter. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way while in the roundabout
The entering vehicle
Whoever signals first
Both proceed with caution
explanation: Vehicles already circulating in a roundabout always have the right-of-way over entering vehicles. The entering driver must wait for a safe gap.

text: At an intersection, you have a green light but there are vehicles still in the intersection from the previous signal cycle. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the intersection to clear before entering
Proceed immediately since you have the green light
Honk to clear the intersection
Enter slowly and navigate around the vehicles
explanation: Even with a green light, you must yield to vehicles already in the intersection. Never enter an intersection until it is clear and you can completely cross.

text: You are approaching an intersection where you want to turn right, and the light is green. What should you do?
choices: Slow down, check for pedestrians and traffic, then turn when safe
Turn at full speed since you have a green light
Stop completely before turning
Turn only if there are no pedestrians anywhere nearby
explanation: Even with a green light, you must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and oncoming traffic before turning. Always slow down and check before completing the turn.

text: Two vehicles arrive at a 4-way stop at the same time. One is turning right, the other is turning left. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle turning right
The vehicle turning left
Both can proceed at the same time
Whoever signals first
explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously and one is turning right, the right-turning vehicle generally has the right-of-way because the turn is less complex and involves less crossing traffic.

text: At an intersection with a flashing red light, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat it as a stop sign
Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop only if other vehicles are present
Proceed at normal speed
explanation: A flashing red light means the same as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when safe.

text: At an intersection with a flashing yellow light, what should you do?
choices: Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop completely
Proceed at normal speed
Treat it as a yield sign
explanation: A flashing yellow light means slow down and proceed with caution. You do not need to stop, but should be alert for potential hazards at the intersection.

text: You are at a 4-way stop and the vehicle on your left arrived just before you. That vehicle is going straight, and you want to turn left. Who proceeds first?
choices: The vehicle on your left that arrived first
You can proceed at the same time
You should proceed first since you are turning
Whoever has more space to maneuver
explanation: At a 4-way stop, vehicles proceed in the order they arrive. The vehicle that arrived first has the right-of-way regardless of the direction they intend to travel.

text: At an intersection, you have a left turn arrow (green arrow) but pedestrians are still crossing. What should you do?
choices: Yield to pedestrians even though you have the arrow
Proceed since you have the green arrow
Honk to alert pedestrians
Turn slowly and expect pedestrians to move
explanation: Pedestrians always have the right-of-way when they are legally in a crosswalk, even if you have a green arrow. You must wait for them to clear before turning.

text: When leaving a parking lot or driveway to enter a street, who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles already on the street
You, as the exiting vehicle
Whoever signals first
Whoever proceeds first
explanation: Vehicles on the street always have the right-of-way over vehicles entering from driveways or parking lots. You must yield before entering the roadway.

text: At a complex intersection with multiple lanes, you are in a left turn lane with a green light (not an arrow). Oncoming traffic has a green light. Pedestrians are crossing the street you want to turn onto. Who goes first?
choices: Pedestrians, then oncoming traffic, then you
You have priority with your green light
Oncoming traffic only
Pedestrians only
explanation: Pedestrians have the highest priority, followed by oncoming straight traffic, and finally left-turning vehicles. You must yield to both pedestrians and oncoming vehicles.

text: In a roundabout, you need to exit but a pedestrian is in the crosswalk at your exit. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian
Proceed slowly since you are exiting
Honk to warn the pedestrian
Take the next exit instead
explanation: Pedestrians always have the right-of-way in crosswalks, including those at roundabout exits. You must stop and wait for them to cross safely.

text: What does a green traffic light mean for your right-of-way?
choices: You may proceed, but must yield to pedestrians and vehicles already in the intersection
You have absolute right-of-way and can proceed immediately
You must stop and then proceed
Only pedestrians may proceed
explanation: A green light means you may proceed through the intersection, but you must still yield to pedestrians and any vehicles already lawfully in the intersection.

text: At a 4-way stop, all four vehicles arrive at exactly the same time. How should this situation be resolved?
choices: Drivers should make eye contact and proceed cautiously one at a time
All vehicles proceed simultaneously
The largest vehicle goes first
Wait for a police officer to direct traffic
explanation: When all vehicles arrive simultaneously at a 4-way stop, drivers should use caution, make eye contact, and communicate to determine a safe order of proceeding.

text: You approach a T-intersection where you are on the terminating street. You have a stop sign. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles on the through street
You, after stopping
Whoever arrives first
Vehicles turning into your street
explanation: At a T-intersection, traffic on the through street has the right-of-way. You must stop and yield to all traffic on the through street before entering.

text: A pedestrian is crossing the street at a marked crosswalk. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian
Proceed if you have a green light
Honk to warn the pedestrian
Speed up to cross before them
explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in marked crosswalks, regardless of traffic signals. Pedestrian safety is the top priority.

text: You see a pedestrian waiting to cross at an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection. What should you do?
choices: Stop and allow the pedestrian to cross
Proceed since there is no marked crosswalk
Slow down but continue through
Honk to indicate they should wait
explanation: Pedestrians have the right-of-way at both marked and unmarked crosswalks at intersections. Drivers must yield to pedestrians crossing in these areas.

text: A pedestrian has a white cane or is using a guide dog. What does this indicate?
choices: The pedestrian is blind or visually impaired and has the right-of-way
The pedestrian is a crossing guard
The pedestrian is conducting a safety demonstration
The pedestrian prefers not to be disturbed
explanation: A white cane or guide dog indicates the pedestrian is blind or visually impaired. These pedestrians always have the right-of-way, and drivers must yield and take extra caution.

text: You are turning right at an intersection and a pedestrian is crossing the street you are turning onto. The pedestrian has a 'Don't Walk' signal. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The pedestrian still has the right-of-way if they are in the crosswalk
You have the right-of-way since the pedestrian's signal says 'Don't Walk'
Whoever reaches the crosswalk first
Neither, both should stop
explanation: Once a pedestrian is in the crosswalk, they have the right-of-way regardless of the pedestrian signal. Drivers must yield to pedestrians already crossing.

text: You approach a school zone during school hours and see children crossing. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to all children crossing
Slow down but continue if safe
Honk to alert children to your presence
Proceed at normal speed if no crossing guard is present
explanation: Children crossing in school zones always have the right-of-way. Drivers must stop and yield to ensure their safety, especially during school hours.

text: A pedestrian is crossing in the middle of the block (not at a crosswalk or intersection). Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way, but should still avoid hitting the pedestrian
The pedestrian always has the right-of-way
Whoever reaches the point first
The pedestrian if they signal to cross
explanation: Pedestrians jaywalking outside of crosswalks must yield to vehicles. However, drivers still have a duty to avoid hitting pedestrians even when the pedestrian is at fault.

text: You are approaching a crosswalk where a pedestrian has just stepped off the curb on the far side of the road (multiple lanes away from you). What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian
Continue since the pedestrian is far away
Slow down slightly but proceed
Honk to alert the pedestrian
explanation: Texas law requires drivers to yield to pedestrians in any part of the crosswalk, not just the lane closest to you. Stop and allow the pedestrian to cross safely.

text: A bicycle is riding on the road in front of you. How should you treat this bicycle?
choices: As a vehicle with the same rights and responsibilities
As a pedestrian that must move to the sidewalk
As an obstacle to avoid quickly
As having less right-of-way than cars
explanation: Bicycles are considered vehicles under Texas law and have the same rights and responsibilities as cars. Treat cyclists with respect and follow all right-of-way rules.

text: You are turning right and there is a bicycle lane to your right. A cyclist is approaching in the bike lane. What should you do?
choices: Yield to the cyclist before turning across the bike lane
Turn quickly before the cyclist reaches you
Honk and proceed with your turn
Signal for the cyclist to stop
explanation: Drivers must yield to cyclists in bike lanes before turning across the lane. Check your mirrors and blind spots, and wait for the cyclist to pass before turning.

text: A pedestrian is on the sidewalk next to the road, not attempting to cross. Do you need to yield?
choices: No, but be prepared to stop if they enter the roadway
Yes, always yield to pedestrians on sidewalks
Yes, if they make eye contact
No, pedestrians on sidewalks have no priority
explanation: Pedestrians on sidewalks are not in the roadway and you do not need to yield. However, stay alert and be ready to stop if they enter the roadway or approach a crosswalk.

text: When can pedestrians cross at a red light?
choices: Never, unless the pedestrian signal shows 'Walk'
Anytime if no vehicles are coming
During the red light phase for vehicles
Only with a crossing guard present
explanation: Pedestrians must obey pedestrian signals just as drivers obey traffic signals. Pedestrians should only cross when their signal shows 'Walk' or the walking person symbol.

text: You are driving on a road with a bike lane. The bike lane is to your right and there are no cyclists present. Can you drive in the bike lane?
choices: Only when turning, merging, or parking where permitted
Yes, if no cyclists are present
Never, under any circumstances
Yes, to pass slow-moving traffic
explanation: Drivers may only enter bike lanes when necessary for turning, merging, or legal parking. Otherwise, bike lanes are reserved exclusively for bicycle traffic.

text: A pedestrian is crossing mid-block against a 'Don't Walk' signal. You have a green light. What should you do?
choices: Slow or stop to avoid hitting the pedestrian, even though you have the right-of-way
Proceed at speed since you have the right-of-way
Honk loudly and maintain speed
Flash your lights and continue
explanation: While the pedestrian is violating the law, drivers still have a duty to avoid collisions. Slow down or stop to prevent hitting the pedestrian, even when you have the legal right-of-way.

text: A bicycle is traveling on the road without a bike lane. Where should the cyclist ride?
choices: As far right as practicable, but still on the roadway
On the left side facing traffic
In the center of the lane at all times
On the sidewalk only
explanation: Cyclists should ride as far to the right as safely practicable when there is no bike lane. They are entitled to use the full lane when necessary for safety.

text: When passing a cyclist on the road, how much space should you give?
choices: At least 3 feet of clearance
At least 1 foot of clearance
As much space as possible, but no specific distance
At least 6 feet of clearance
explanation: Texas law requires drivers to give at least 3 feet of clearance when passing a cyclist. If you cannot safely pass with this distance, slow down and wait for a safe opportunity.

text: You see a pedestrian with a white cane crossing at an intersection. The light turns green for you. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to completely finish crossing before proceeding
Proceed slowly and honk to alert them
Drive around the pedestrian carefully
Flash your lights to signal them to hurry
explanation: Blind or visually impaired pedestrians always have the right-of-way. Wait patiently and allow them to cross completely before proceeding, regardless of your signal.

text: You are approaching a crosswalk where the pedestrian signal is flashing 'Don't Walk' but no pedestrians are present. Can you turn?
choices: Yes, if there are no pedestrians in or approaching the crosswalk
No, you must wait for a solid 'Walk' signal
Yes, but only if you honk first
No, the flashing signal means stop
explanation: A flashing 'Don't Walk' signal is for pedestrians who haven't started crossing. If no pedestrians are present or approaching, you may proceed with caution after yielding appropriately.

text: A cyclist is making a left turn at an intersection from the left turn lane. You are behind them. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the cyclist to complete the turn, treating them as any other vehicle
Pass the cyclist on the right before they turn
Honk to encourage them to move faster
Move to the straight lane to avoid waiting
explanation: Bicycles are vehicles and have the right to use turn lanes and make turns like any other vehicle. Wait patiently for the cyclist to complete their turn safely.

text: You see a pedestrian crossing sign warning. What does this mean?
choices: Be alert for pedestrians crossing in this area
Pedestrians must use this crossing only
Stop and wait for pedestrians
Pedestrians are prohibited in this area
explanation: Pedestrian crossing warning signs alert drivers to areas where pedestrians frequently cross. Slow down and be prepared to yield to pedestrians.

text: A group of pedestrians is crossing at a crosswalk. Half have crossed and are now on the other side, while the rest are still crossing. Can you proceed?
choices: No, wait for all pedestrians to completely finish crossing
Yes, you can proceed in the empty lanes
Yes, if you proceed slowly
Yes, if you honk first
explanation: You must wait for all pedestrians to completely clear the crosswalk before proceeding. Even if some lanes appear clear, more pedestrians may still be crossing.

text: Can pedestrians walk in the roadway if a sidewalk is available?
choices: No, pedestrians must use the sidewalk when one is available
Yes, pedestrians can always choose to walk in the road
Yes, but only during daylight hours
Yes, if they walk facing traffic
explanation: Texas law requires pedestrians to use sidewalks when they are available. Walking in the roadway when a sidewalk exists is prohibited.

text: You see a bicycle crossing warning sign. What should you do?
choices: Be alert for cyclists crossing or entering the roadway
Stop and wait for cyclists
Cyclists are prohibited from crossing here
Sound your horn when you see cyclists
explanation: Bicycle crossing warning signs indicate areas where cyclists frequently cross or enter the roadway. Slow down and watch carefully for cyclists.

text: A cyclist is riding in the center of a narrow lane. Can you pass them?
choices: Only if you can change lanes completely or provide at least 3 feet of clearance
Yes, by squeezing past them in the same lane
Yes, by honking first to move them over
No, you must follow behind until they move
explanation: Cyclists may take the full lane when necessary for safety. You may only pass by changing lanes completely or ensuring at least 3 feet of clearance, never by squeezing past in the same lane.

text: You are stopped at a red light. A pedestrian starts crossing against the 'Don't Walk' signal. What should you do when your light turns green?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to finish crossing before proceeding
Proceed slowly and honk
Proceed since you have the green light
Turn on your hazard lights and wait
explanation: Even if a pedestrian is crossing illegally, you must yield and allow them to finish crossing safely. Never enter an intersection with pedestrians still in your path.

text: A cyclist is approaching a stop sign at the same time as you. You are also at a stop sign from a different direction. Who proceeds first?
choices: Follow normal right-of-way rules as if the cyclist is a vehicle
You always have priority over cyclists
The cyclist must always yield to motor vehicles
Whoever is faster proceeds first
explanation: Bicycles are treated as vehicles and follow the same right-of-way rules. Apply the same rules you would for two motor vehicles arriving at a stop sign.

text: If a sidewalk is not available, which side of the road should pedestrians walk on?
choices: On the left side, facing oncoming traffic
On the right side, with traffic flow
In the center of the road
On whichever side has better lighting
explanation: When no sidewalk is available, pedestrians should walk on the left side of the road facing oncoming traffic so they can see vehicles approaching.

text: At an intersection, you have a green light. A pedestrian with a white cane is crossing against the pedestrian signal, and a cyclist is making a left turn in front of you. Who has priority?
choices: The pedestrian with the white cane has highest priority, then the cyclist, then you
You have priority with your green light
The cyclist has priority as they arrived first
All should proceed with caution simultaneously
explanation: Blind or visually impaired pedestrians always have the highest priority. Cyclists are treated as vehicles. You must yield to both the pedestrian and the cyclist before proceeding.

text: You are driving on a road where there is both a bike lane and a sidewalk. Where should cyclists ride?
choices: In the bike lane, not on the sidewalk
On the sidewalk only
Either the bike lane or sidewalk, their choice
On the road with motor vehicles
explanation: When a bike lane is present, cyclists should use it rather than the sidewalk. Bike lanes are designed specifically for bicycle traffic and provide the safest route.

text: You are turning into a driveway and must cross a sidewalk. Pedestrians are walking on the sidewalk. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Pedestrians on the sidewalk
You, as you are entering private property
Whoever reaches the driveway first
Neither, both must stop
explanation: Pedestrians on sidewalks always have the right-of-way over vehicles entering or exiting driveways. You must stop and yield before crossing the sidewalk.

text: A pedestrian is standing at the curb at a marked crosswalk, looking as if they want to cross. Are you required to stop?
choices: Yes, if the pedestrian indicates intent to cross or steps into the roadway
No, only if they are already in the crosswalk
Yes, pedestrians always have priority near crosswalks
No, they must wait for you to pass
explanation: Texas law requires drivers to yield to pedestrians who have shown intent to cross by stepping into the roadway or clearly indicating they wish to cross.

text: An emergency vehicle with flashing lights and sirens is approaching from behind. What should you do?
choices: Pull over to the right and stop
Speed up to get out of the way
Stop immediately in your current lane
Change lanes to the left
explanation: When an emergency vehicle approaches with lights and sirens, you must pull over to the right side of the road and stop until it passes. This provides a clear path for the emergency vehicle.

text: You hear sirens from an emergency vehicle but don't see it. What should you do?
choices: Slow down, be alert, and be prepared to pull over
Continue driving normally
Stop immediately
Speed up to clear the area
explanation: If you hear sirens but don't see the emergency vehicle, slow down and stay alert. Be prepared to pull over when you locate the vehicle's position.

text: An emergency vehicle is approaching with lights and sirens while you are in an intersection. What should you do?
choices: Clear the intersection first, then pull over
Stop immediately in the intersection
Speed through the intersection
Back up to let the emergency vehicle through
explanation: Never stop in an intersection, even for an emergency vehicle. Continue through the intersection, then pull over to the right and stop as soon as safely possible.

text: A school bus has stopped with its red lights flashing and stop sign extended. You are on the same side of the road. What must you do?
choices: Stop at least 20 feet away and remain stopped until the bus moves or the lights stop flashing
Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop briefly then proceed if no children are visible
Change lanes and pass the bus slowly
explanation: When a school bus displays flashing red lights and an extended stop sign, you must stop at least 20 feet away and remain stopped until the bus begins moving or the lights stop flashing.

text: A school bus is stopped with red flashing lights on a two-lane road. You are approaching from the opposite direction. What should you do?
choices: Stop and remain stopped until the bus moves or the lights stop flashing
Slow down but proceed with caution
Proceed normally as the bus is on the other side
Stop only if you see children
explanation: On an undivided two-lane road, traffic in both directions must stop for a school bus with flashing red lights. This protects children who may cross the road.

text: You are on a highway separated by a median or barrier. A school bus on the other side has stopped with red lights flashing. Must you stop?
choices: No, you may proceed with caution
Yes, you must always stop for school buses
Only if the median is less than 10 feet wide
Yes, but only if children are present
explanation: On a divided highway with a physical barrier or median, traffic traveling in the opposite direction does not need to stop for a school bus. The barrier prevents children from crossing.

text: What do flashing yellow lights on a school bus indicate?
choices: The bus is preparing to stop; slow down and prepare to stop
You may pass the bus
The bus is stopped; you must stop
Children are boarding; stop immediately
explanation: Flashing yellow lights on a school bus mean it is preparing to stop. Slow down and be ready to stop when the red lights begin flashing.

text: An emergency vehicle is parked on the side of the road with flashing lights. What should you do?
choices: Move over to a non-adjacent lane if safe, or slow down to 20 mph below the speed limit
Maintain your speed and lane
Stop behind the emergency vehicle
Flash your lights and proceed
explanation: Texas Move Over law requires drivers to move over to a non-adjacent lane if safe. If you cannot move over, you must slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit.

text: You are at a red light and an emergency vehicle behind you has lights and sirens on. There is no room to pull to the right. What should you do?
choices: Stay stopped and wait for the light to change or for the emergency vehicle to find another route
Drive through the red light to clear the way
Back up to make room
Pull into the intersection
explanation: Never run a red light, even for an emergency vehicle. Stay stopped and the emergency vehicle will navigate around you or wait for the light to change.

text: A funeral procession is passing through an intersection. The procession has a green light but you arrived at the intersection first. What should you do?
choices: Yield to the entire funeral procession
Proceed since you arrived first
Proceed if you have a green light
Honk to alert the procession
explanation: Funeral processions have the right-of-way at intersections. All vehicles in the procession may proceed together, and other traffic must yield to the entire procession.

text: How can you identify a funeral procession?
choices: Vehicles have headlights on and often have funeral flags or follow a hearse
Vehicles are driving slowly
Vehicles have their hazard lights on
There is always a police escort
explanation: Funeral processions typically have headlights on during the day, may display funeral flags, and follow a hearse. Not all processions have police escorts.

text: Can you pass an emergency vehicle that is stopped on the side of the road with lights flashing?
choices: Yes, but you must move over or slow down significantly
No, you must stop behind it
Yes, at normal speed in the far lane
No, you must turn around and find another route
explanation: You may pass a stopped emergency vehicle, but you must follow the Move Over law: change lanes if safe, or slow down to 20 mph below the speed limit.

text: You are on a single-lane road and an emergency vehicle approaches from behind with lights and sirens. What should you do?
choices: Pull over to the right as far as possible and stop
Speed up to find a wider area
Stop in the middle of the road
Continue until you reach a parking lot
explanation: Even on a single-lane road, pull as far to the right as safely possible and stop. The emergency vehicle will navigate around you if there is room, or wait until you can move further.

text: A school bus has its red lights flashing. When can you proceed?
choices: When the red lights stop flashing and the stop sign is retracted
When you don't see any children
After stopping for 10 seconds
When the bus driver waves you on
explanation: You may only proceed past a stopped school bus when the red lights stop flashing and the stop sign is retracted, indicating it is safe for the bus to resume travel.

text: You are on a five-lane road (two lanes each direction with a center turn lane). A school bus on your side has stopped with red lights flashing. Must you stop?
choices: Yes, all traffic on your side must stop
No, you can change lanes and proceed
Only if you are in the lane next to the bus
No, five-lane roads are exempt
explanation: All traffic traveling in the same direction as a stopped school bus must stop, regardless of the number of lanes. You cannot change lanes to go around the bus.

text: A city bus is signaling to merge back into traffic from a bus stop. What should you do?
choices: Yield and allow the bus to merge when safe
Maintain your speed and position
Speed up to pass the bus
Honk to indicate the bus should wait
explanation: Texas law requires drivers to yield to buses signaling to re-enter traffic from a designated stop. Slow down and allow the bus to merge safely.

text: Can you follow closely behind an emergency vehicle with lights and sirens to get through traffic faster?
choices: No, this is illegal and dangerous
Yes, if you maintain a safe following distance
Yes, but only on highways
Yes, if you also turn on your hazard lights
explanation: It is illegal to follow within 500 feet of an emergency vehicle responding to a call. This practice is dangerous and can result in tickets and fines.

text: You are approaching an emergency vehicle with flashing lights stopped on a two-lane road with no room to move over. What should you do?
choices: Slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit
Stop completely behind the emergency vehicle
Proceed at the posted speed limit
Turn around and find another route
explanation: If you cannot safely move over to a non-adjacent lane, you must slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit when passing emergency vehicles with flashing lights.

text: At an intersection, a school bus with flashing red lights is stopped on your right, an emergency vehicle with sirens is approaching from behind, and a pedestrian is in the crosswalk ahead. Who has priority?
choices: The pedestrian, then the school bus, then the emergency vehicle
The emergency vehicle has priority over all
The school bus has priority over all
Follow order of arrival
explanation: Pedestrian safety is paramount. The school bus stop creates a protected zone for children. The emergency vehicle can navigate around once pedestrians are clear and the bus situation is resolved.

text: Can you pass a school bus that is stopped with flashing red lights on a multi-lane highway if you are in the far left lane?
choices: No, all lanes of traffic in your direction must stop
Yes, if you are more than two lanes away
Yes, if you slow down significantly
Yes, if the highway is divided
explanation: All traffic traveling in the same direction as the school bus must stop when red lights are flashing, regardless of how many lanes separate you from the bus.

text: You want to change lanes on a highway. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle already in the lane you want to enter
You, if you signal first
Whoever is traveling faster
You, if you complete the lane change quickly
explanation: The vehicle already established in a lane has the right-of-way. You must yield to traffic in the lane you wish to enter and only merge when it is safe.

text: You are merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles already on the highway
You, as the merging vehicle
Whoever is traveling faster
Whoever signals first
explanation: Traffic already on the highway has the right-of-way. Merging vehicles must yield, adjust speed, and find a safe gap to enter the highway traffic.

text: You are on a highway and see a vehicle merging from an entrance ramp. What should you do?
choices: Maintain your speed and position, or move over if safe to help them merge
Speed up to prevent them from merging in front of you
Slow down and stop to let them in
Honk to warn them you have the right-of-way
explanation: While highway traffic has the right-of-way, it is courteous and safer to move over or adjust speed if possible to help merging traffic. If not possible, maintain your speed and position.

text: You are on a highway and need to exit. Another vehicle is in your blind spot. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle in your blind spot
You, because you need to exit
Whoever signals first
Both should proceed with caution
explanation: The vehicle already in the lane has the right-of-way. If a vehicle is in your blind spot, you must slow down or speed up to create space before changing lanes to exit.

text: Two vehicles are merging onto a highway from separate entrance ramps at the same point. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle that is ahead or on the right
The vehicle traveling faster
Both must stop and yield
The vehicle on the left
explanation: When two vehicles are merging simultaneously, standard right-of-way rules apply. The vehicle ahead or to the right has priority, but both must yield to highway traffic.

text: You are passing a slower vehicle on a two-lane highway. An oncoming vehicle appears. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The oncoming vehicle in its own lane
You, because you started passing first
Whoever is traveling faster
Both should slow down
explanation: Oncoming traffic always has the right-of-way in their own lane. If you cannot complete a pass safely before oncoming traffic reaches you, you must abort the pass and return to your lane.

text: You are entering a highway from a parking lot or driveway. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: All vehicles already on the highway
You, if you signal properly
Whoever proceeds first
You, if no vehicles are immediately visible
explanation: When entering any roadway from private property like a parking lot or driveway, you must yield to all traffic already on the road. Wait for a safe gap before entering.

text: You see a merge warning sign on the highway. What does this indicate?
choices: Traffic from another roadway will be merging ahead; be prepared to adjust
You must merge into another lane immediately
All traffic must stop
Your lane is ending
explanation: A merge warning sign alerts you that traffic from an entrance ramp or merging lane will be joining your roadway. Be prepared to adjust speed or move over if safe.

text: You are driving on a highway and your lane is ending (forced merge). Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles in the continuing lane
You, because your lane is ending
Whoever signals first
Whoever is ahead
explanation: When your lane is ending and you must merge, you must yield to traffic in the continuing lane. You cannot force your way in; wait for a safe gap.

text: You are on a highway entrance ramp with a yield sign. When can you merge?
choices: Only when there is a safe gap in highway traffic
After stopping completely
Whenever you signal your intention
When you reach the end of the ramp
explanation: A yield sign means you must give right-of-way to highway traffic and merge only when there is a safe gap. Adjust your speed to find an appropriate opening.

text: You are on a three-lane highway. You are in the center lane. Vehicles are merging from the right, and a vehicle on your left is signaling to move into your lane. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way in your current lane over both vehicles
The merging vehicle has priority
The vehicle on your left has priority
Whoever signals first
explanation: As the vehicle established in your lane, you have the right-of-way over both vehicles trying to enter your lane. Both the merging and lane-changing vehicles must yield to you.

text: You are exiting a highway and need to cross lanes of traffic. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles in the lanes you need to cross
You, because you are exiting
Whoever signals first
You, if you are running out of road
explanation: When changing lanes to exit, you must yield to all vehicles in the lanes you need to cross. Plan ahead and move over early to avoid last-minute dangerous maneuvers.

text: On a two-lane road, you are behind a slow-moving vehicle and want to pass. There is a dashed yellow line. What should you do?
choices: Check for oncoming traffic, and pass only if you can complete it safely before any oncoming vehicle arrives
Pass whenever you want since the line is dashed
Honk first, then pass
Wait until the yellow line is completely gone
explanation: A dashed yellow line indicates passing is permitted, but you must yield to oncoming traffic. Only pass when you can see far enough ahead and complete the pass safely.

text: You are on a highway acceleration lane (entrance ramp). The lane is about to end and you need to merge, but there is steady traffic and no gaps. What should you do?
choices: Adjust your speed to create a gap, or use the shoulder if necessary and safe, rather than forcing a merge
Force your way into traffic
Stop at the end of the ramp and wait for a gap
Sound your horn and merge gradually
explanation: Never stop on an acceleration lane unless absolutely necessary. Adjust speed to find or create a gap. If the lane ends, carefully use the shoulder before forcing an unsafe merge.

text: You see a lane ends sign. What should you do?
choices: Merge into the continuing lane when it is safe to do so
Stop and wait for an opening
Speed up to merge before the lane ends
Continue to the very end and force your way in
explanation: A lane ends sign gives you advance warning to merge safely into the continuing lane. Signal, check blind spots, and merge when there is a safe gap in traffic.

text: You are passing a vehicle on a two-lane road. Oncoming traffic suddenly appears closer than expected. What should you do?
choices: Abort the pass and return to your lane immediately
Complete the pass as quickly as possible
Flash your lights at the oncoming vehicle
Both you and the oncoming vehicle should pull over
explanation: If oncoming traffic appears during a pass and you cannot complete it safely, immediately abort the pass and return to your original lane. Oncoming traffic has the right-of-way in their lane.

text: You are on a highway and traffic ahead is slowing down for a vehicle entering from an entrance ramp. What should you do?
choices: Slow down with traffic and maintain safe following distance
Change lanes immediately to avoid slowing down
Speed up to pass before the merging vehicle
Flash your lights at the merging vehicle
explanation: When traffic slows to allow merging vehicles, maintain a safe following distance and slow down with traffic. Abrupt lane changes or speed increases can cause accidents.

text: You are on a two-lane highway passing a slow vehicle. Another faster vehicle behind you is tailgating. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way to complete your pass safely before returning to your lane
The tailgating vehicle should pass both of you
You should abort your pass for the faster vehicle
The slow vehicle you are passing
explanation: Once you have legally and safely begun passing, you have the right to complete the maneuver. The tailgating vehicle must wait. However, complete your pass promptly and return to your lane.

text: You are preparing to merge onto a highway. Should you stop on the entrance ramp?
choices: Only if absolutely necessary; use the ramp to accelerate and merge smoothly
Yes, always stop before merging
Yes, unless you have a clear view
No, never stop under any circumstances
explanation: Entrance ramps are designed for acceleration to match highway speed and merge smoothly. Stopping creates a dangerous situation. Only stop if there is no other safe option.

text: You are on a highway in heavy traffic. Your exit is coming up, but you are in the left lane and there is no gap to move right. What should you do?
choices: Miss your exit and take the next one
Force your way across lanes immediately
Stop and wait for traffic to let you in
Drive on the shoulder to reach your exit
explanation: Never make unsafe lane changes or stop on a highway. If you cannot safely reach your exit, miss it and take the next exit. Plan ahead in the future to move over earlier.

text: At a 4-way stop, you arrive at the same time as another vehicle to your left. You are both turning right onto the same road. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way since you are on the right
The vehicle on your left
Both can proceed simultaneously
Whoever has a larger turning radius
explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Even though both are turning onto the same road, standard right-of-way rules apply.

text: You are turning left from a minor road onto a major highway. Traffic on the highway is heavy in both directions. When can you proceed?
choices: Only when there is a sufficient gap in both directions to complete the turn safely
When traffic in one direction clears
After waiting 30 seconds
When another driver signals you to go
explanation: When turning left onto a highway, you must yield to traffic from both directions. Wait for a gap large enough to enter and cross or merge safely without causing others to brake.

text: You are at an intersection waiting to turn left. Your light turns yellow, then red, but you are already in the intersection. What should you do?
choices: Complete your turn when oncoming traffic stops
Reverse back behind the stop line
Turn immediately before the light turns red
Wait in the intersection through the entire red light cycle
explanation: If you are already legally in the intersection when the light turns red, you have the right to clear the intersection by completing your turn once oncoming traffic stops.

text: At an intersection with a four-way flashing red light, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat each direction as a stop sign and proceed in order of arrival
Proceed with caution without stopping
Yield to all traffic then proceed
The main road has priority
explanation: When all directions have flashing red lights, treat the intersection as a four-way stop. Each vehicle must stop completely and proceed in order of arrival, yielding to the right if simultaneous.

text: You are in a roundabout. An emergency vehicle with lights and sirens is trying to enter. What should you do?
choices: Exit the roundabout at the next available exit and pull over
Stop immediately in the roundabout
Speed up to clear the roundabout quickly
Continue normally since you have the right-of-way
explanation: Never stop in a roundabout. Continue to the next exit, then pull over to the right to allow the emergency vehicle to pass. Clear the roundabout as quickly and safely as possible.

text: At a T-intersection, you are on the through road. A vehicle on the terminating road has a stop sign. You want to turn left onto the terminating road. Who proceeds first?
choices: You proceed first as you are on the through road
The vehicle with the stop sign proceeds first
Both proceed with caution
The vehicle going straight always has priority
explanation: Traffic on the through road has the right-of-way over traffic entering from the terminating road. You may turn left without yielding to the stopped vehicle, though caution is always wise.

text: You are merging onto a highway. The vehicle behind you on the highway is tailgating the car in front of it. Should you merge into that gap?
choices: No, find a safer gap with adequate following distance
Yes, signal and merge quickly
Yes, the tailgater will make room
Yes, you have the right to merge
explanation: Never merge into an unsafe gap with inadequate following distance. Look for a safe gap where vehicles have proper spacing. Merging into a tight space increases collision risk.

text: You are at a complex intersection. You have a green left turn arrow. A pedestrian with a guide dog is crossing the street you want to turn onto, but their signal shows 'Don't Walk'. An oncoming car runs the red light. Who do you yield to?
choices: Both the pedestrian and the red-light-running vehicle to avoid collisions
Neither, you have a green arrow
Only the pedestrian
Only the vehicle running the red light
explanation: Safety always comes first. Despite having the legal right-of-way with your green arrow, you must avoid collisions with both the pedestrian and the vehicle violating the signal.

text: You are driving on a highway in the left lane. You see a slower vehicle ahead in your lane. Do you have the right to stay in the left lane?
choices: No, the left lane is for passing; move right after passing
Yes, you can drive in any lane at any time
Yes, if you are going the speed limit
Only if there is heavy traffic
explanation: The left lane on multi-lane highways is designated for passing. After passing slower traffic, you should move back to the right lane to allow others to pass.

text: You are on a two-lane road following a mail carrier who stops frequently. Can you pass?
choices: Yes, if it is safe and legal to pass
No, you must always follow postal vehicles
Yes, postal vehicles do not have right-of-way
No, unless they signal you to pass
explanation: Mail carriers do not have special right-of-way privileges while delivering mail. You may pass when it is safe and legal to do so, following normal passing rules.

text: At an uncontrolled intersection, you are turning left and another vehicle is approaching from the right going straight. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right going straight has right-of-way over your left turn
You have the right-of-way since you arrived first
Both should proceed with caution
Whoever signals first
explanation: At an uncontrolled intersection, the vehicle on the right has priority. Additionally, left-turning vehicles must yield to straight-through traffic. The vehicle on the right going straight has double priority.

text: You are exiting a parking garage onto a busy street. A pedestrian is walking on the sidewalk approaching your exit. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The pedestrian on the sidewalk
You, as you are exiting private property
Whoever reaches the driveway first
You, if you honk to alert the pedestrian
explanation: Pedestrians on sidewalks always have the right-of-way over vehicles entering or exiting driveways. You must stop and yield before crossing the sidewalk to enter the street.

text: You approach a railway crossing with flashing lights. The gates are not down yet. What should you do?
choices: Stop and do not proceed until the lights stop flashing
Proceed quickly before the gates come down
Slow down and proceed with caution
Proceed if you don't see a train
explanation: Flashing lights at a railway crossing mean a train is approaching. Stop at least 15 feet from the tracks and do not proceed until the lights stop flashing and gates are fully raised.

text: At an intersection with a traffic light, you want to go straight and have a green light. Do you need to yield to any traffic?
choices: Yes, yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and vehicles already in the intersection
No, green means you have absolute right-of-way
Only to emergency vehicles
Only if the light just turned green
explanation: Even with a green light, you must yield to pedestrians lawfully in the crosswalk and any vehicles already in the intersection before you enter.

text: You are on a highway that is ending (merging into another highway). Does traffic on the continuing highway need to yield to you?
choices: No, you must yield to traffic on the continuing highway
Yes, they must let you merge
Whoever is traveling faster has priority
You have equal priority
explanation: When your highway is ending and merging into another highway, you must yield to traffic on the continuing highway. Watch for merge signs and find a safe gap to merge.

text: At a 4-way stop, you arrive first. As you begin to proceed, another vehicle runs the stop sign from your right. What should you do?
choices: Stop or slow down to avoid a collision, even though you have the right-of-way
Continue since you have the right-of-way
Honk and maintain speed
Accelerate to assert your right-of-way
explanation: Having the legal right-of-way does not guarantee safety. Always be prepared to yield to avoid a collision, even when another driver violates traffic laws.

text: You see a one-way sign. A vehicle is driving the wrong way toward you. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You do, but avoid the collision by pulling to the right if possible
The wrong-way driver must turn around
Whoever is driving faster
Neither, both should stop
explanation: You have the legal right-of-way on a one-way street, but safety is paramount. Pull to the right and avoid the wrong-way driver, then report the dangerous situation if possible.

text: You are in the intersection waiting to turn left. The light is green. Oncoming traffic is heavy but stops for a pedestrian in the crosswalk. The light turns yellow. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to clear and oncoming traffic to stop, then complete your turn
Turn immediately while oncoming traffic is stopped
Back up out of the intersection
Wait through the red light until the next green
explanation: If you are legally in the intersection, you must clear it. Wait for the pedestrian to clear and oncoming traffic to stop, then complete your turn even if the light is red.

text: Two vehicles approach an uncontrolled intersection from perpendicular directions. Vehicle A is on a wider road, Vehicle B is on a narrow road. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right, regardless of road width
Vehicle A on the wider road
Vehicle B on the narrow road
Both should stop and negotiate
explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way regardless of road size. Road width does not determine priority unless signs or signals indicate otherwise.

text: You are turning right at a red light (where permitted). A vehicle to your left is turning left onto the same road with a green arrow. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle with the green left turn arrow
You, making the right turn
Both can proceed simultaneously
Whoever signals first
explanation: A green arrow gives that driver the right-of-way. When turning right on red, you must yield to all traffic, including vehicles with a green arrow turning onto the same road.
